Abstract
In contrast to Cr3+, equal zero-field splittings (ZFSs) are observed for Fe3+ in all cesium alums, suggesting its local geometry to be independent of these host lattices. The intrinsic ZFS parameter for water as ligand is considerably larger than for O2−.

LEHMANN Institut fur Physikalische Chemie, Westfalische Wilhelms-Universitat, D-4400 Munster/Westfalen, Federal Republic of Germany Received 4 November 1985; in final form 5 December 1985 In contrast to Cr3'1', equal zero-field splittings (ZFSs) are observed for Fe3'1' in all cesium alums, suggesting its local geometry to be independent of these host lattices. The intrinsic ZFS parameter for water as ligand is considerably larger than for O2-. The determination of the true local geometries for impurity ions in crystals in cases of valence and/or size mismatch is still a challenging problem. A determination of the bond distances for sites of high symmetry has re- cently been attempted from the isotropic ligand hyper- fine splittings in the electronic paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra for Mn2"1" in fluorides [1]. Average bond distances for transition-metal ions may also be ob- tained from their ligand-field spectra, and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) is a more recent and more accurate method not restricted to a particular class of elements. Cr3"*" in ruby [2] and Mn2"1" in fluorides [3] are illustrative examples for their application. However, only in the rather rare cases of structurally equivalent ligands does an average bond length provide the full answer, and the required molar concentrations around 1% for the EXAFS method are a likely restriction in cases of larger mismatch. For the S-state ions Mn2"1" and Fe3"1" the zero- field splitting (ZFS) patterns of their EPR spectra offer a method of as yet unexcelled sensitivity and accuracy for determination of the local geometries in lower than cubic site symmetries. They very closely reflect the geometries of the first coordination spheres of these ions as demonstrated by numerous successful applications of the superposition model (SPM) [4] for the same valence and very similar sizes of host and impurity ion. This method, initially 202 tested for the S-state ions Gd3"1" and Eu2"1" thus allows determination of effective distortions for every di- rection which results from the sums of angular and bond-length deviations of the individual ligands from undistorted geometries. An unambiguous breakdown into the individual contributions of each ligand is not (yet?) possible, but for axial site symmetries with completely equivalent ligands an assessment of the local relaxation can be attempted as soon as a reliable value of the intrinsic ZFS parameter b^ is known from investigation of systems in which such relaxation effects are of negligible importance. A considerable influence of such relaxation effects is apparent from data for Fe3"'" in Al sites in minerals [5,6]. We here report results for Fe3"1" in cesium alums for which complete crystal structure data are available [7]. EPR data for other alums and for Cr3"1" from the literature are also evaluated for comparison. EPR spectra of single crystals of the cesium alums ofAl3"*", Ga3"*" and In3"*" doped by addition of 1 mole% of Fe3"1" to the growth solutions, were measured at Q-band (between 33.6 and 33.8 GHz) and room temperature. Fig. 1 shows the angular variation of the line positions for the cesium gallium alum for rotation around a [ 111 ] crystal axis. The corresponding diagrams for the other two alums were very similar, and as the data in table 1 show, their ZFS parameters b^ obtained from a least-squares fitting program were equal within experimental error. This does, however, not hold for all alums since in those of the smaller monovalent cations significantly smaller ZFSs were found as also shown in table L Equal distortions can result from two extreme situations: either the geometries of the FetH^O)3"1' units are the same as in pure iron alum in all cesium alums or the bond lengths for Fe3'1" are the same as in the host compounds and only the bond angles are changed. Table 2 shows the deviations of the trigonal angles from the ideal value of 54.74 for the cesium alums and the deviations necessary for the second possibility. We see that in all cases the angles are larger than the ideal value corresponding to a trigonal compression. The required changes in the bond angles are not large, but nevertheless it seems more likely that the bond angles adjust to the value for the pure compound *. It thus appears that this is an extreme case of local lattice relaxation, the fact that it has never been observed before in any other system indicates that most likely more than one special condition must be fulfilled. We believe there are three such conditions which allow or at least favor this lattice relaxation: (a) Existence of distinct Mil"1' (or perhaps also iso- lated MX^~) groups. For ions bound to anions like Cft~ or F" which in turn are coordinated to other constituents of the structure such an independence of the ZFS of the nature of the host ion has never been observed. It may be that molecular-type structures with neutral UX^ units also favor a local geometry independent of the host ion as suggested by EPR data for Cr3"1' in acetylacetonates [15]. (b) A type of structure in which other, sufficiently large constituents provide sufficient space for the Miy units to allow them to expand easily if a larger cation substitutes the host ion. Although our evidence is still fairly incomplete, we expect smaller monovalent cations to be much less favorable for this extreme * Since the signs of b^ are not known, changes of the bond angles in the opposite direction (by practically the same amount) are also possible in principle. For Fe3"1" in the double nitrates [M" (H^O^] 3 [X(N03)g] 2- 6H2U with M = Zn and X = La and Ce almost identical b^ values were ob- served [17], but in this case the sizes of the trivalent ions are also very similar, and the authors believe the iron to occupy interstitial positions. Likewise the very similar ZPSs for Mn2"1" in compounds of this type [18] are not very conclusive. For Cr3"1" in the cesium alums b^ changes slightly to less negative values with increasing size of the host ion [10,19]. Similar changes to more positive values are observed for alums of the smaller monovalent cations as shown in fig. 2. If these variations are interpreted in terms of the SPM they indicate decreasing trigonal angles with increasing size of the host ion. But since the validity of the SPM has not yet been demonstrated experimentally and is questioned for theoretical reasons [20] for Cr3"1- it may well be that ZFS for this ion does not reflect the geometry of its first coordination sphere, but also depends on changes at larger distances. We thus cannot yet draw any definite conclusions about the lattice relaxations of this ion. The ZFSs for Fe3"1" in other alums should also be in- vestigated. Methylammonium alums with still larger lattice constants than the cesium alums would be the most interesting. For the methylammonium alum of Al a b^ very similar to that m the cesium alums was determined [9], but the low accuracy does not rule out the possibility that it is different. Investigation of selenate alums would also be interesting, and judging from the results for Cr3"'" shown in fig. 2, results very similar to those for the rubidium sulfate alums would be expected. __ The intrinsic ZFS parameter b^ for FeO^O)3"1" can be determined from the data for the cesium gallium alum and a value of 2.21 (70) cm-1 is obtained neglecting the small lattice relaxation. Judging from the known data for O2" as ligand [6,13] the sign should be negative, but the absolute value in any case is at least three times larger than for O2-. This com- pletely contradicts the results for the isoelectronic Mn2"1" where the intrinsic ZFS parameters always were "atomic" properties independent of the actual nature of the ligand. The reasons for the different behaviour of Fe3"1" are still completely obscure, and more ex- perimental as well as theoretical investigations are called for.
